item.title: Hailey Bieber’s Billion-Dollar Clapback: Why Her ELF Beauty Deal Is the Only Response She Needed
item.dc:creator: Gio Adriano
item.description: When Hailey Bieber graced the cover of Vogue France earlier this year, the spotlight should’ve been on her. But it wasn’t—at least not for the right reasons. item.content:encoded:
When Hailey Bieber graced the cover of Vogue France earlier this year, the spotlight should’ve been on her. But it wasn’t—at least not for the right reasons. In a moment that went viral, her husband, Justin Bieber, reportedly made a sarcastic remark about the shoot, leading fans to speculate that he wasn’t entirely supportive of her solo success.

Fast forward just weeks later, and Hailey is the one making headlines again—but this time, it’s for something far bigger: her beauty brand Rhode is reportedly being acquired by ELF Beauty in a deal valued at US$1.1 billion (approximately S$1.5 billion).

And just like that, Hailey didn’t need to defend herself. She didn’t post a Notes app message or clap back in an interview. She just let her billion-dollar brand do the talking.

Hailey Bieber launched Rhode in 2022 with a clear vision: clean, minimalist skincare that worked. Despite early skepticism from critics who called it “just another celebrity beauty line,” Rhode quickly became a Gen Z favourite, selling out multiple times and gaining cult status for products like the Peptide Lip Treatment and Glazing Milk. Hailey herself remained the face and creative force behind the brand, ensuring her voice—soft-spoken but certain—carried through in every campaign.

The ELF deal cements her not just as a founder, but a serious businesswoman. According to reports, Hailey will remain involved with the brand even after the acquisition, signalling that this isn’t a celebrity cash-out—it’s a strategic move to scale even further.

What makes this moment resonate isn’t just the billion-dollar number—it’s the contrast. From being side-eyed on her own cover shoot to standing at the helm of one of the year’s biggest beauty acquisitions, Hailey’s rise is a reminder that silence can be strength, and building something of your own is the best response to being underestimated—even by people close to you.

In a world that still often defines women by who they’re with, Hailey is showing the power of betting on yourself. And for every woman who’s ever been told she’s “just someone’s wife,” this story hits different.

After all, success may not be loud—but it’s always heard.

item.title: Running Barefoot, Winning Gold: How an 11-Year-Old Filipina Taught Us the Power of Determination
item.dc:creator: Gio Adriano
item.description: On her 11th birthday, young Trixia Anne Arellano did something extraordinary—she broke a national record in the 200-metre dash at a major youth sports event in the Philippines. What made her win even more remarkable? She ran barefoot. item.content:encoded:
On her 11th birthday, young Trixia Anne Arellano did something extraordinary—she broke a national record in the 200-metre dash at a major youth sports event in the Philippines. What made her win even more remarkable? She ran barefoot.

Representing Western Visayas in the Philippines’ 65th Palarong Pambansa (a national student-athlete competition similar to Singapore’s National School Games), Trixia finished the 200-metre race in just 26.40 seconds—surpassing a 17-year-old record. The next day, she added another gold medal to her name by winning the 100-metre sprint.

But beyond the medals and broken records, it was how she won that captured hearts across the region. Trixia had worn shoes in the preliminary rounds and didn’t win. But during the finals, she made the bold decision to go barefoot—something she felt more comfortable with, and the results speak for themselves.

Her story is a powerful reminder to parents everywhere that sometimes, the best thing we can do is support our children in finding their own stride—literally and figuratively. Whether it’s allowing them to try something unconventional, or backing their decisions that may seem unusual at first glance, Trixia’s triumph shows us that confidence, self-awareness, and heart can make a world of difference.

As Singaporean parents raising children in an increasingly competitive world, it’s easy to focus on results—be it academic scores or performance in co-curricular activities. But stories like Trixia’s remind us that resilience, self-belief, and the courage to be different are just as important.

So the next time your child wants to try something their own way (within safe limits, of course), it might just be the beginning of a winning journey.

item.title: Is Goat Milk Good for Pregnancy? Everything Moms Need to Know
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Joyce Almario
item.description: Is goat milk safe and beneficial during pregnancy? Discover all the essential facts, benefits, risks, and expert tips for moms-to-be considering goat milk in their prenatal diet.
item.content:encoded:
When you’re expecting, every bite and sip counts. While cow’s milk is a common staple in pregnancy diets, goat milk is gaining traction among health-conscious moms. Known for its easy digestibility and rich nutrient profile, many wonder: Is goat milk good for pregnancy?

This article dives deep into the facts, separating myth from reality and helping you make informed, bump-friendly choices.

Nutritional Benefits of Goat Milk During Pregnancy

Goat Milk During Pregnancy: Is It Safe and Nutritious?

1. A Powerful Dose of Essential Nutrients

Goat milk is packed with key nutrients that support both mom and baby:

Calcium – Crucial for fetal bone and tooth development.

Vitamin A – Supports healthy skin, vision, and immune function.

Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin) – Promotes energy production and cell growth.

Protein – Aids in the formation of baby’s organs and tissues.

2. Easier on the Digestive System

Many expectant moms find goat milk easier to digest than cow’s milk because:

It contains smaller fat globules, leading to quicker digestion.

It has less alpha-casein, a protein that some people find difficult to process.

This makes goat milk a possible solution for those with mild lactose sensitivities though it’s not lactose-free.

3. Boosts the Immune System

Goat milk naturally contains bioactive compounds like selenium and zinc that can help strengthen the immune system, which undergoes changes during pregnancy.

 

Things to Be Cautious About 1. Pasteurization is Non-Negotiable

Never consume raw goat milk during pregnancy. It can contain dangerous bacteria like Listeria, Salmonella, or E. coli, which can lead to:

Miscarriage

Premature labor

Severe illness for both mother and baby

Always opt for pasteurized goat milk only.

2. Watch for Fortification

Unlike commercial cow’s milk, goat milk may lack folic acid and vitamin D unless it’s fortified. These nutrients are essential for:

Preventing birth defects (especially folic acid)

Supporting calcium absorption and immune health (vitamin D)

Choose fortified versions or ensure your prenatal vitamins cover these needs.

3. Allergy Awareness

While goat milk proteins are different from cow milk, they can still trigger allergies. If you’ve had dairy sensitivities or allergies in the past, consult your doctor before adding goat milk to your diet.

 

How Much Goat Milk Can You Drink While Pregnant?

Most health professionals recommend 1–2 servings per day (about one cup each) as part of a balanced prenatal diet. Goat milk can be used in:

Smoothies

Cereal or oatmeal

Cooking or baking

Homemade yogurt or cheese

Expert Tip: Speak With Your Doctor

Every pregnancy is unique. While goat milk can be highly nutritious, it’s essential to discuss dietary choices with your OB-GYN or dietitian, especially if you’re managing gestational diabetes, hypertension, or any digestive disorders.

 

Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) 1. Is goat milk safe to drink during pregnancy?

Yes, as long as it is pasteurized, goat milk is generally safe to consume during pregnancy. It provides valuable nutrients such as calcium, protein, and vitamin A.

2. What are the benefits of goat milk for pregnant women?

Goat milk is rich in essential nutrients, easier to digest than cow’s milk for some women, and supports immune function. It can help with fetal development, energy levels, and digestive comfort.

3. Can goat milk cause allergies during pregnancy?

While rare, some people can be allergic to goat milk proteins. If you have a known dairy allergy or experience symptoms like bloating or skin reactions, consult your doctor before consuming.

4. Is goat milk better than cow milk during pregnancy?

Goat milk is easier to digest and may be less allergenic for some, but cow milk is often fortified with folic acid and vitamin D. The best choice depends on your nutritional needs and how your body reacts.

5. How much goat milk should a pregnant woman drink per day?

1–2 cups per day is generally safe, depending on your overall diet. It’s best to incorporate it as part of a balanced meal plan approved by your healthcare provider.

6. Should I drink goat milk instead of taking prenatal vitamins?

No. Goat milk can complement a healthy pregnancy diet but should not replace prenatal vitamins, which provide essential nutrients like folic acid and iron.

7. Can I drink goat milk if I’m lactose intolerant during pregnancy?

Goat milk contains less lactose than cow’s milk but still contains some. If you’re lactose intolerant, speak to your doctor or try lactose-free or plant-based alternatives.

 

Final Thoughts

Goat Milk During Pregnancy: Is It Safe and Nutritious?

Goat milk can be a fantastic addition to your pregnancy diet if it’s pasteurized, fortified, and consumed in moderation. It delivers a rich array of nutrients, supports digestion, and can be a refreshing alternative to traditional dairy.

However, make sure you’re mindful of potential allergies and nutrient gaps. With the right guidance, this creamy, gentle milk can nourish both you and your baby beautifully throughout your pregnancy journey.

item.title: This Chemistry Teacher Says the Toughest Formula to Crack is Fatherhood
item.dc:creator: Miko Pagaduan
item.description: Despite all his achievements — being a Cambridge examiner, teaching over 400 students, founding a centre — Kelvin says fatherhood remains his greatest and most humbling role.
item.content:encoded:
With Father’s Day just around the corner, there’s a lot of talk about what it means to be a father — the provider, the protector, the planner. But in real life, none of these roles come with a manual. And as Singaporean parents juggling careers, school stress, and growing kids, we know that sometimes it feels like we’re just winging it.

Now imagine doing all that while teaching one of the most feared subjects in school: Chemistry.

Kelvin Ang, former MOE JC teacher, Cambridge examiner, and the founder of The Chemistry Practice, doesn’t just teach Chemistry. He lives the balancing act every father knows well: trying to be present at home while making a difference at work. He’s spent over a decade helping hundreds of students master one of the most complex subjects in the A-Level syllabus. But it wasn’t until he became a father himself that his approach to teaching — and life — truly transformed.

This Father’s Day, Kelvin offers something a little different. Not a formula. Not a solution. But a reflection on what teaching Chemistry has taught him about being a father, and what being a father has taught him about teaching Chemistry.

  From Military Control Tower to Classroom (and Then Home)

Kelvin didn’t start out with a periodic table and whiteboard in hand. In fact, he spent six years as an Air Traffic Controller in the Air Force after national service.

“At that point, I started asking myself — is this really what I want to do long-term? I realised maybe it was time to try something I had always wanted to do but never got around to — teaching.”

The other career tugging at him was teaching — something he had shelved but never truly let go of.

So, he pivoted. He entered the MOE system, taught in Junior Colleges, and eventually worked at a leading Chemistry tuition centre. And while his students were achieving solid grades — many scoring As and Bs — something else was nagging at him.

“By having my own centre, I have the freedom to design my own way of teaching — how I want to approach each topic, and what kinds of questions to go through in class. It’s something I’m really proud of, because it allows me to develop and customise everything myself.”

And so in 2021, in the middle of raising two young kids with his wife of 14 years, he launched The Chemistry Practice — a space designed not just for academic achievement, but for deeper learning and support.

Source: Kelvin Ang

  Teaching Chemistry, While Raising Humans

Ask any parent. Raising kids is an education in itself. But ask a father who’s also a teacher, and he’ll tell you just how intertwined the two really are.

“When you’re handling your own kids, your expectations of them tend to be higher, I would say. I do get a little bit less patient with my kids.”

“Somehow, my wife always comments that I’m more patient with my students than with my own kids,” Kelvin laughs.

It’s a moment many parents can relate to. We expect our own children to “know better” or to behave the way we hope they will. But the truth? Parenting — like Chemistry — is full of variables.

“But you learn the way to break down difficult concepts into easier, digestible small bites. So this actually helps me in explaining the difficult concepts to the older kids that I have in the tuition centre.”

  Why Chemistry is Like Parenting

If you’ve ever supported your teen through A-Levels, you know Chemistry isn’t just about mixing chemicals and watching things bubble.

Source: Kelvin Ang

“So it is multifaceted, and then you also have organic chemistry, where you need to be able to draw the structures correctly. As a Chemistry teacher, you’re teaching them a lot of different techniques to solve questions — calculations, drawings, graphing,” Kelvin explains. “It’s really multifaceted; it’s not just calculation-based. This is what makes Chemistry difficult.”

Sounds familiar?

Parenting, too, is a series of evolving challenges. What works at age 4 doesn’t work at 14. And when your child suddenly doesn’t “get” something in school — or life — it’s tempting to panic.

But Kelvin has a calming counter-perspective.

“So while academic achievements are important, they shouldn’t come at the expense of mental health,” he says. “It’s essential for schools, parents, and teachers to work together to find the right balance and to support both the academic goals as well as the mental and emotional health of our children.”

So he encourages both parents and students to be realistic — but proactive. Be present, ask better questions, and support with patience, not pressure.

  Real Support for Real Exams

Let’s get practical for a second. For A-Level Chemistry students, it’s not just about understanding — it’s about recalling tons of information.

One tool Kelvin swears by? Digital flashcards.

“For A-Level Chemistry, they have to remember close to 60 or more reactions,” he explains. “That’s where flashcards come in. They help students recall the reactions they must remember. I always tell them, on the way to school, just take 5 to 10 minutes to go through the flashcards. If you do it consistently every day, over time, you’ll be able to remember all the reactions.”

It’s a small, doable habit that teaches consistency — something every father hopes to instil in their children.

He also focuses on exposing students to all levels of questions — easy to brutally difficult — so they don’t panic during the exam. In other words, life skills — disguised as Chemistry prep.

If your teen is struggling with Chemistry or you simply want them to build real confidence before their A-Levels, check out The Chemistry Practice. Kelvin and his team don’t just teach Chemistry — they teach students how to think, apply, and believe in their own ability.

“If you’re still struggling with Chemistry at this point and need some guidance or help to improve your results, we’re here to help. We know exactly what the exam requires, and we can help bridge that gap.”

This Father’s Day, maybe the best gift you can give your child… is a little bit more belief. From you, and from the right guidance along the way.

  Fatherhood, The Hardest and Most Rewarding Subject of All

Despite all his achievements — being a Cambridge examiner, teaching over 400 students, founding a centre — Kelvin says fatherhood remains his greatest and most humbling role.

Source: Kelvin Ang

“I think finding a balance is never an easy task, because there’s no perfect formula — everyone’s job and work requirements are different.”

It’s this humility that makes his story so relatable. For Singaporean parents constantly wondering if we’re doing enough, his message is simple: You don’t have to be perfect. Just be present.

He believes that the most powerful thing a father (or any parent) can do is to keep showing up — with patience, curiosity, and the willingness to grow alongside our kids.

Source: Kelvin Ang

“It’s not just about spending time together — the time needs to be meaningful. For example, my wife and I make it a point that during our meals, we put away our phones so we can have real conversations with the kids — ask them how their day is going, what’s been bothering them, talk about their friends.”

  Celebrate the Fathers Who Are Still Learning, Too

This Father’s Day, maybe it’s not about the big gestures or fancy brunches. Maybe it’s about recognising the quiet efforts — the late-night revision sessions, the mini pep talks, the consistent presence even when you’re running on empty.

Kelvin Ang’s journey proves that fatherhood isn’t about having the perfect formula — it’s about trial and error, controlled chaos, and sometimes just holding the beaker steady while everything else heats up.

Being a father means being the constant in your child’s life equation, even when their variables are all over the place.

He believes that the most powerful thing a father (or any parent) can do is to keep showing up — with patience, curiosity, and the willingness to grow alongside our kids.

"It’s not just about spending time together — the time needs to be meaningful. For example, my wife and I make it a point that during our meals, we put away our phones so we can have real conversations with the kids — ask them how their day is going, what’s been bothering them, talk about their friends."

 
Celebrate the Fathers Who Are Still Learning, Too
This Father’s Day, maybe it’s not about the big gestures or fancy brunches. Maybe it’s about recognising the quiet efforts — the late-night revision sessions, the mini pep talks, the consistent presence even when you’re running on empty.
Kelvin Ang’s journey proves that fatherhood isn’t about having the perfect formula — it’s about trial and error, controlled chaos, and sometimes just holding the beaker steady while everything else heats up.
Being a father means being the constant in your child’s life equation, even when their variables are all over the place.

item.title: Is Full Cream Milk Good for Pregnancy? Here’s What You Need to Know
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Joyce Almario
item.description: Discover whether full cream milk is safe and beneficial during pregnancy. Learn about its nutritional value, pros and cons, and expert tips for expectant mothers.
item.content:encoded:
Pregnancy marks a transformative journey. One where every dietary choice can influence the health and development of your growing baby. Among the many foods pregnant women ponder over, milk is a frequent topic of debate. More specifically, is full cream milk good for pregnancy?

While some tout it as a powerhouse of nutrition, others raise concerns about its fat content.

In this article, we explore the benefits, drawbacks, and expert recommendations surrounding the consumption of full cream milk during pregnancy.

Benefits of Full Cream Milk During Pregnancy

Is Full Cream Milk Good for Pregnancy? Here’s What You Need to Know

1. Nutrient-Rich for Mother and Baby

Full cream milk is a natural source of essential nutrients such as:

Calcium: Supports bone development in the fetus and maintains maternal bone strength.

Protein: Essential for fetal growth and development of organs.

Vitamin D & A: Important for immune function, vision, and the formation of healthy skin and bones.

2. May Be Fortified with DHA

Some full cream milk brands are fortified with DHA (Docosahexaenoic Acid), a crucial omega-3 fatty acid known to support brain and nervous system development in babies.

3. Enhances Energy Levels

Thanks to its higher fat and calorie content, full cream milk offers an energy boost that can help combat fatigue often experienced during pregnancy.

 

Potential Drawbacks to Consider 1. High in Saturated Fat

Full cream milk has a higher percentage of saturated fat compared to low-fat versions. Consuming it excessively may lead to:

Unnecessary weight gain

Increased cholesterol levels

Higher risk of pregnancy-related hypertension

2. Calorie-Dense

Each glass of full cream milk contains around 150 calories. For women monitoring their pregnancy weight or with gestational diabetes, this may not be ideal.

3. Safety First: Choose Pasteurized Only

Unpasteurized milk can harbor harmful bacteria like Listeria, which poses serious risks during pregnancy. Always opt for pasteurized milk to ensure safety for both mom and baby.

 

Expert Recommendations

Moderation is key: One to two servings of full cream milk daily is generally considered safe unless advised otherwise by a healthcare provider.

Personalized advice matters: Every pregnancy is different. Speak with a nutritionist or OB-GYN before making any major dietary changes.

Consider alternatives: If full cream milk isn’t suitable for you, low-fat milk, lactose-free options, or plant-based milk fortified with calcium and vitamin D are excellent alternatives.

Sip Smart, Grow Strong

Is Full Cream Milk Good for Pregnancy? Here’s What You Need to Know

Full cream milk can be a valuable addition to a pregnancy diet, rich in essential nutrients that support both mom and baby.

However, as with all things during pregnancy, balance and personalization are key. Whether you choose full cream or opt for a lighter version, ensuring you’re getting adequate nutrients is what truly counts.

Always consult your healthcare provider and make informed decisions that align with your unique health needs. After all, you’re not just feeding yourself, you’re nurturing the future.

item.title: Mental Disorders Now Leading Health Concern Among Singaporean Tweens, Study Finds
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Joyce Almario
item.description: Mental disorders in SG youth are now the leading cause of disability and death among ages 10–14, a new Lancet study reveals. Learn what’s driving the trend and how parents can help.
item.content:encoded:
As parents, we worry about grades, screen time, sleep, and nutrition. But how often do we stop to check in on our child’s mental health?

A new study published in The Lancet Public Health has highlighted something every parent in Singapore needs to hear. Mental disorders are now the leading cause of disability and death among children aged 10 to 14.

This isn’t just a statistic. It’s a wake-up call.

 

Alarming Statistics

In 2021 alone, Singapore recorded approximately 653,000 diagnoses of mental disorders, with prevalence rates at 12.8% for males and 11.7% for females. Among the most commonly reported conditions were anxiety (affecting 185,000 individuals) and depression (144,000 individuals).

The impact is particularly severe among tweens. The 10–14 age group now faces mental illness as the primary contributor to both disability and mortality, a stark contrast to traditional concerns such as infectious diseases or physical injuries.

Causes Behind the Crisis

Mental Disorders Now Leading Health Concern Among Singaporean Tweens, Study Finds

Experts point to several contributing factors:

Academic Pressure and Social Media: High expectations in school and the 24/7 presence of social media have led to increased stress, performance anxiety, and low self-esteem among children and teens.

Family and Social Changes: Rising rates of family breakdowns, social isolation, and Westernized societal shifts have also been linked to a growing mental health burden.

The Lingering Impact of COVID-19: The pandemic disrupted routines, isolated families, and created widespread uncertainty. This is particularly hard on young, developing minds.

“Clinically, mental health challenges often emerge early in life and, if unaddressed, can lead to years of lost potential,” said Professor Alina Rodriguez from NUS Medicine, one of the collaborators on the paper.

It’s Not Just Teens: Older Adults at Risk Too

The study also found a threefold rise in mental disorders among those aged 70 and above compared to 1990. As people live longer, depression often follows declining physical health, making mental health an important issue across all life stages.

 

What Can Parents Do?

Watch for signs like mood swings, withdrawal, sleep disturbances, or academic decline.

Start conversations early about emotions and mental well-being.

Normalize seeking help — show your child that mental health care is just as important as physical health care.

Reach out to school counselors, family doctors, or mental health helplines.

Resources for Parents and Families

Mental and emotional well-being is just as important as physical health. Parents who suspect their child is struggling with anxiety, depression, or other mental health challenges can access support through various local resources:

IMH Mental Health Helpline: 6389-2222 (24/7)

Samaritans of Singapore: 1-767 / WhatsApp 9151-1767 (24/7)

Chat for Youth Mental Health: 6493-6500/1

mindline.sg and tinklefriend.sg for self-help and chat support

 

The Takeaway

Mental Disorders Now Leading Health Concern Among Singaporean Tweens, Study Finds

Raising emotionally strong children means going beyond just physical health and academic achievements. This study is a reminder: mental health is health. If we want to support our children’s growth and potential, it starts with making space for their feelings, struggles, and healing.

Let’s not wait for crisis to care. Let’s start the conversation today.

Sources:

Lancet Public Health

NUS Yong Loo Lin School of Medicine

Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation (IHME)

Straits Times

item.dc:creator: Gio Adriano
item.description: In a significant advancement for male reproductive health, a new non-hormonal contraceptive implant named ADAM has demonstrated effectiveness for at least two years in early clinical trials. Developed by U.S.-based biotech company Contraline, this innovation presents a promising alternative to traditional male contraceptive methods like condoms and vasectomies. How ADAM Works The ADAM implant utilises […]
item.content:encoded:
In a significant advancement for male reproductive health, a new non-hormonal contraceptive implant named ADAM has demonstrated effectiveness for at least two years in early clinical trials. Developed by U.S.-based biotech company Contraline, this innovation presents a promising alternative to traditional male contraceptive methods like condoms and vasectomies.

How ADAM Works

The ADAM implant utilises a water-soluble hydrogel that is injected into the vas deferens—the ducts responsible for transporting sperm. This hydrogel acts as a physical barrier, preventing sperm from mixing with semen during ejaculation. Over time, the hydrogel is designed to naturally dissolve, potentially restoring fertility without the need for surgical intervention.

The implantation procedure is minimally invasive, taking less than 30 minutes and requiring only local anaesthesia. This approach offers a less permanent solution compared to vasectomy and avoids the daily maintenance associated with condoms.

Is the ADAM Implant Safe?

Yes—early trial data suggests that ADAM is safe and well-tolerated. In a Phase 1 clinical trial with 25 healthy male participants, no serious adverse effects were reported. In fact, the two men who reached the 24-month milestone showed no detectable sperm in their semen.

The implant is also reversible, with the hydrogel expected to dissolve naturally over time. Contraline is actively developing procedures for early removal and reversal as well.

Still Under Critical Trials

While early results are promising, it’s important to note that ADAM is still undergoing clinical trials. Regulatory approval has been granted for Phase 2 trials in Australia, involving 30–50 participants to further assess the implant’s safety, efficacy, and reversibility.

Kevin Eisenfrats, CEO of Contraline, shared:

“There’s a major unmet need for more male contraceptive options. ADAM is designed to be a long-lasting yet reversible alternative to vasectomy, and we’re excited about what the data is showing so far.”

The company is also working on at-home sperm test kits so users can easily track the implant’s effectiveness.

A Big Step Towards Shared Family Planning

Currently, the responsibility for contraception often falls on women, who may experience side effects from hormonal birth control. ADAM implant, the new male birth control option, could offer a balanced, low-maintenance solution for couples, enabling men to take an active role in family planning without long-term commitment or daily routines.

For more information on the ADAM implant and ongoing clinical trials, visit Contraline’s official website.

item.title: SMART and KKH Develop First-of-Its-Kind Device (BLIPI) to Profile Newborns’ Immune Function
item.dc:creator: Gio Adriano
item.description: In a revolutionary leap for neonatal healthcare, researchers from the Critical Analytics for Manufacturing Personalized-Medicine (CAMP) and Antimicrobial Resistance (AMR) interdisciplinary research groups (IRGs) of the Singapore-MIT Alliance for Research and Technology (SMART), MIT’s research enterprise in Singapore, in collaboration with KK Women’s and Children’s Hospital (KKH), have co-developed BLIPI — the BiophysicaL Immune Profiling […]
item.content:encoded:
In a revolutionary leap for neonatal healthcare, researchers from the Critical Analytics for Manufacturing Personalized-Medicine (CAMP) and Antimicrobial Resistance (AMR) interdisciplinary research groups (IRGs) of the Singapore-MIT Alliance for Research and Technology (SMART), MIT’s research enterprise in Singapore, in collaboration with KK Women’s and Children’s Hospital (KKH), have co-developed BLIPI — the BiophysicaL Immune Profiling for Infants device. This cutting-edge technology allows doctors to analyse a newborn’s immune function in under 15 minutes, using only a single drop of blood.

This innovation promises to transform early diagnostics in newborn care, offering hope for timely intervention in life-threatening conditions like sepsis and necrotising enterocolitis (NEC) — especially crucial for premature babies.

The Importance of Early Immune Profiling in Newborns

Each year, conditions like newborn sepsis and NEC claim the lives of countless premature infants. These illnesses progress rapidly, yet current diagnostic tools are slow, invasive, and require up to 1 ml of blood — a major concern for premature babies with a total blood volume of just 50 ml.

“Our goal was to create a diagnostic tool that works within the unique constraints of neonatal care — minimal blood volume, rapid turnaround, and high sensitivity,” said Dr Kerwin Kwek, Research Scientist at SMART CAMP and SMART AMR. “BLIPI represents a major step forward by providing clinicians with fast, actionable immune health data using a non-invasive method, where it can make a real difference for newborns in critical care.”

What Is BLIPI and How Does It Work?

BLIPI uses microfluidic technology to measure how immune cells, particularly white blood cells, respond to infection by analysing changes in their size and flexibility. This provides direct evidence of immune system activity, complementing traditional indicators like CRP levels, white cell counts, and neutrophil ratios.

This real-time immune profiling was validated in a study published in Pediatric Research, where 19 infants — both full-term and premature, were tested at multiple timepoints. Notably, BLIPI detected early immune changes in a premature baby who developed a serious blood infection, showcasing its clinical potential.

Transforming Care in NICUs and Beyond

Because BLIPI is portable and produces results at the bedside, it eliminates the delay and stress of sending blood samples to external labs.

“With BLIPI, a single prick to the baby’s finger or heel can give us rapid insights into the infant’s immune response within minutes,” said Assistant Professor Yeo Kee Thai, Senior Consultant at the Department of Neonatology at KKH. “This allows us to tailor treatments more precisely and respond faster to give these fragile babies the best chance at a healthy start not just in their early days, but throughout their lives.”

KKH, which cares for about two-thirds of all babies born weighing less than 1,500 grams in Singapore, sees BLIPI as a vital addition to its neonatal care arsenal.

Looking Ahead: Global Impact and Continued Research

The SMART and KKH team plans larger clinical trials to further validate BLIPI’s effectiveness across diverse newborn populations and medical conditions. The goal is to refine its design for widespread use in hospitals worldwide and potentially enable pharmaceutical companies to monitor real-time immune responses during clinical trials of neonatal therapies.

“BLIPI exemplifies our vision to bridge the gap between scientific innovation and clinical need,” said Professor Jongyoon Han, co-lead Principal Investigator at SMART CAMP, Principal Investigator at SMART AMR. “By leveraging microfluidic technologies to extract real-time immune insights from whole blood, we are not only accelerating diagnostics but also redefining how we monitor immune health in fragile populations.”

BLIPI is not just a diagnostic device — it’s a lifeline for the most fragile members of society. Through rapid, minimally invasive, and highly accurate immune profiling, it empowers doctors to act fast and smart, offering premature babies a stronger start in life.

Why is BLIPI crucial for premature infants?

Premature babies have tiny blood volumes and are highly susceptible to infections. BLIPI’s low blood requirement and rapid response make it ideal for fast, life-saving decisions.

Where will BLIPI be used first?

BLIPI will first be deployed in Singapore’s neonatal care units like KKH, with potential for broader international implementation as trials expand.

item.title: Almond Milk for Pregnancy: Safety, Benefits & How to Include It in Your Diet
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Joyce Almario
item.description: Is almond milk safe during pregnancy? Learn about its benefits, potential risks, and how to include almond milk in a healthy prenatal diet.
item.content:encoded:
Pregnancy comes with a flurry of questions especially about what you can and should eat or drink. For many moms-to-be, traditional dairy may cause digestive issues, lactose intolerance, or just not sit right. That’s where almond milk steps in: a creamy, nutty, plant-based alternative that’s both trendy and potentially nourishing. But is almond milk truly good for pregnancy?

From its vitamin-rich profile to important safety considerations, this article delivers the facts you need to make confident dietary choices during this transformative time.

 

What Is Almond Milk?

Almond Milk for Pregnancy: Safety, Benefits & How to Include It in Your Diet

Almond milk is a plant-based beverage made by blending soaked almonds with water and then straining the mixture. The result is a smooth, slightly nutty milk that’s naturally free from lactose and cholesterol. Commercial almond milk is often fortified with essential nutrients such as calcium, vitamin D, and B12, key players in a healthy pregnancy.

It comes in various forms: sweetened or unsweetened, flavored (like vanilla), and shelf-stable or refrigerated. For pregnancy, unsweetened and fortified options are generally considered best.

Is Almond Milk Safe During Pregnancy?

Yes, almond milk is safe to consume during pregnancy for most women. It’s a gentle, low-calorie alternative to dairy that suits many dietary preferences, including vegan and lactose-free diets. However, as with any food, moderation is key.

Pregnant women with nut allergies should, of course, avoid almond milk altogether. Additionally, always check for added sugars and unnecessary additives when buying store-bought options. Ideally, choose organic, unsweetened, and fortified almond milk to maximize health benefits while minimizing risks.

Nutritional Benefits of Almond Milk for Pregnant Women Low in Calories and Sugar (When Unsweetened)

Unsweetened almond milk typically contains just 30–40 calories per cup, making it a light, hydrating choice for women managing pregnancy weight gain or gestational diabetes.

Naturally Lactose-Free

Many pregnant women develop lactose sensitivity. Almond milk is an excellent alternative that won’t cause bloating, gas, or discomfort associated with dairy.

Rich in Vitamin E

Almond milk is naturally high in vitamin E, an antioxidant that supports skin health and may help reduce inflammation. It also supports fetal cell development and immune function.

Fortified with Calcium and Vitamin D

These two nutrients are essential for building your baby’s bones and teeth. Fortified almond milk can offer up to 30% of the recommended daily intake of calcium and 25% of vitamin D per cup.

Source of B Vitamins and Magnesium

These micronutrients are vital for energy metabolism, nerve function, and muscle health—supporting both mother and child throughout the pregnancy journey.

FAQs

Almond Milk for Pregnancy: Safety, Benefits & How to Include It in Your Diet

1. Can almond milk help with pregnancy bloating?

Yes, its lactose-free composition can reduce digestive discomfort and bloating for women sensitive to dairy.

2. Is it safe to drink almond milk every day while pregnant?

Yes, 1–2 servings per day of fortified, unsweetened almond milk is generally safe for most pregnant women.

3. Does almond milk have enough calcium for pregnancy needs?

Fortified almond milk can provide significant amounts of calcium, but it should be complemented with other calcium-rich foods.

4. Can almond milk affect breast milk production?

There’s no evidence that almond milk interferes with lactation. It can be included as part of a balanced diet.

5. Is homemade almond milk safer than store-bought?

Homemade almond milk avoids additives and preservatives but may lack key fortifications like calcium and vitamin D. Choose what suits your nutritional needs best.

A Gentle Boost to Your Prenatal Nutrition

Almond milk isn’t just a delicious and refreshing beverage. It’s a versatile, nutrient-rich companion to your pregnancy diet. Whether you’re avoiding dairy or simply want to diversify your nutrition, this plant-based milk offers a safe and beneficial alternative.

Just remember to choose unsweetened, fortified versions and always check in with your healthcare provider if you have dietary restrictions or allergies.

With a little planning, almond milk can be a nourishing sip that supports both your well-being and your baby’s growth every step of the way.

It comes in various forms: sweetened or unsweetened, flavored (like vanilla), and shelf-stable or refrigerated. For pregnancy, unsweetened and fortified options are generally considered best.

Is Almond Milk Safe During Pregnancy?
Yes, almond milk is safe to consume during pregnancy for most women. It's a gentle, low-calorie alternative to dairy that suits many dietary preferences, including vegan and lactose-free diets. However, as with any food, moderation is key.
Pregnant women with nut allergies should, of course, avoid almond milk altogether. Additionally, always check for added sugars and unnecessary additives when buying store-bought options. Ideally, choose organic, unsweetened, and fortified almond milk to maximize health benefits while minimizing risks.

Low in Calories and Sugar (When Unsweetened)
Unsweetened almond milk typically contains just 30–40 calories per cup, making it a light, hydrating choice for women managing pregnancy weight gain or gestational diabetes.
Naturally Lactose-Free
Many pregnant women develop lactose sensitivity. Almond milk is an excellent alternative that won’t cause bloating, gas, or discomfort associated with dairy.
Rich in Vitamin E
Almond milk is naturally high in vitamin E, an antioxidant that supports skin health and may help reduce inflammation. It also supports fetal cell development and immune function.
Fortified with Calcium and Vitamin D
These two nutrients are essential for building your baby’s bones and teeth. Fortified almond milk can offer up to 30% of the recommended daily intake of calcium and 25% of vitamin D per cup.
Source of B Vitamins and Magnesium
These micronutrients are vital for energy metabolism, nerve function, and muscle health—supporting both mother and child throughout the pregnancy journey.

FAQs

1. Can almond milk help with pregnancy bloating?
Yes, its lactose-free composition can reduce digestive discomfort and bloating for women sensitive to dairy.
2. Is it safe to drink almond milk every day while pregnant?
Yes, 1–2 servings per day of fortified, unsweetened almond milk is generally safe for most pregnant women.
3. Does almond milk have enough calcium for pregnancy needs?
Fortified almond milk can provide significant amounts of calcium, but it should be complemented with other calcium-rich foods.
4. Can almond milk affect breast milk production?
There’s no evidence that almond milk interferes with lactation. It can be included as part of a balanced diet.
5. Is homemade almond milk safer than store-bought?
Homemade almond milk avoids additives and preservatives but may lack key fortifications like calcium and vitamin D. Choose what suits your nutritional needs best.

A Gentle Boost to Your Prenatal Nutrition
Almond milk isn’t just a delicious and refreshing beverage. It’s a versatile, nutrient-rich companion to your pregnancy diet. Whether you’re avoiding dairy or simply want to diversify your nutrition, this plant-based milk offers a safe and beneficial alternative.
Just remember to choose unsweetened, fortified versions and always check in with your healthcare provider if you have dietary restrictions or allergies.
With a little planning, almond milk can be a nourishing sip that supports both your well-being and your baby’s growth every step of the way.

item.dc:creator: Gio Adriano

item.content:encoded:
Looking for an exciting way to bond with your kids while nurturing their curiosity? Look no further than the Live It Up – Bringing Engineering to Life STEM Fair 2025, Singapore’s premier hands-on STEM event. From August 14 to 16, the Sands Expo & Convention Centre will transform into a dynamic space where science, technology, engineering, and innovation come alive—perfect for kids, teens, and parents alike.

What is Live It Up – Bringing Engineering to Life?

Organised by NTU’s College of Engineering in collaboration with all five Polytechnics and the Science Centre Singapore, and supported by the Ministry of Education, this annual event celebrates the spirit of innovation, sustainability, and creativity. Over three days, visitors can expect:

Free Entry

Interactive STEM-centric workshops

Talks from industry experts

Exciting tech exhibitions

Interactive family games and races

Whether you’re a parent looking to expose your child to future tech or a curious student eager to tinker and explore, Live It Up offers something for everyone.

Why Families Should Attend

Live It Up is designed with family fun and education in mind. With zones dedicated to Eat, Play, Love, and Grow, every family member will find something to enjoy:

Upper Primary students can experiment and build

Teens and JC students can discover potential careers

Parents can join talks and learn about future education paths

Best of all, it’s the perfect weekend activity that blends fun with learning.

Exciting Workshops That Kids Will Love

From robotics to sustainable science, the workshops are both hands-on and age-appropriate:

Build and Code LEGO Robots

Let your child engineer and control a robot using intuitive coding kits.

Drone Flying and Coding

Watch them learn simple programming and fly drones safely.

3D Design and Printing Fun

They’ll create and print their own 3D designs—imagination meets tech.

DIY Robotic Arm Construction

Great for older kids, this session dives into circuitry and hardware.

Make Biodegradable Paper Soap

A fun, eco-conscious craft that teaches hygiene and sustainability.

Making Kimchi and Kombucha

The science of fermentation is both delicious and educational.

Do Not Miss the Talks

Engage in powerful conversations with innovators and changemakers:

Women in Engineering Panel

Empowering stories and advice for young girls in STEM.

From Engineering to Agritech by Leonard Teo

Learn how one engineer turned to sustainable farming.

My Journey into AI and Data Science by HTX’s Tan Jing Shen

A real-life tech transformation story.

Biomedical Engineering Pathways by Temasek Poly

A must-attend for parents planning their child’s future.

Game On: Join the ‘Live It Up! Unlock the Adventure’s Amazing Race

Turn your visit into a fun-filled family mission.

Scan QR codes around the event to collect points, complete quests, and win awesome prizes.

The more you explore, the better your chances to win.

Winners will be revealed during the Prize Giving Ceremony on August 16.

Explore the Innovation Zones

With interactive booths and showcases from Singapore’s top institutions, families will experience:

Eat Zone: Future food, fermentation, and health innovation

Play Zone: Robots, drones, 3D tech, and virtual reality

Love Zone: AI farming, healthcare analytics, machine learning

Grow Zone: Sustainable development and environmental engineering

Plus, exhibitions from A*STAR, SMRT, SFA, and more.

Practical Information for Parents

Dates: 14 to 16 August 2025

Venue: Sands Expo & Convention Centre, Halls A & B

Time:

Thursday and Friday: 9 AM to 6 PM

Saturday: 10 AM to 8 PM (Last entry 7 PM)

Entry: Free

Some workshops may require advance sign-up.

Wrap-Up: A Weekend of Learning and Family Bonding

The Live It Up – Bringing Engineering to Life STEM Fair 2025 is more than an event—it’s a journey into the future, where kids discover passions, parents get inspired, and everyone learns together. Don’t miss this unforgettable experience that’s educational, interactive, and, above all, fun for the whole family.

FAQs

Is there a registration fee?

No. Entry is free, but some workshops may require advance sign-up.

Are the workshops suitable for young children?

Most are designed for Upper Primary and above. Age levels are clearly marked.

Can we participate in the Amazing Race without pre-registration?

Yes. Just scan the QR codes at the event to get started.

Will there be food available at the venue?

Yes. Sands Expo & Convention Centre offers numerous family-friendly dining options.

item.content:encoded:
Looking for the perfect family-friendly event this September school holidays? The global sensation CoComelon is bringing its first-ever live stage show to Singapore, and it’s going to be a sing-and-dance experience your little ones won’t forget.

What Is CoComelon: Sing-A-Long LIVE?

Credit: Biz Trends

For the first time, CoComelon: Sing-A-Long LIVE! is coming to Singapore, featuring beloved characters JJ, Cody, Nina, Cece, and Ms. Appleberry. The live show will take place at the Sands Theatre, Marina Bay Sands on 27 and 28 September 2025.

Families can look forward to a fun-packed 75-minute performance full of nursery rhymes that young children know and love, such as:

If You’re Happy and You Know It

Wheels on the Bus

Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes

Freeze Dance

Adding to the excitement is a special guest appearance by Blippi, who will perform fan-favourite “The Excavator Song.” This makes the show a double treat for young fans of both CoComelon and Blippi.

Ticket Information and Discounts

Tickets are priced from $78 to $138 (excluding booking fees). An early bird discount of 12% will be available from 8 to 11 May 2025, so parents are encouraged to book early.

Tickets can be purchased via:

Marina Bay Sands website

SISTIC

Why It’s Perfect for Families

CoComelon is a global hit among preschoolers for a reason. With catchy, educational songs and colourful characters, it helps toddlers learn concepts like numbers, letters, and everyday routines—all through music and play.

Blippi’s addition to the show makes it even more exciting. Known for making everyday learning fun, his energy and enthusiasm add another layer of joy for children.

The live show is suitable for children aged 2 to 6. With multiple showtimes across two days and a runtime that’s just right for short attention spans, it’s an ideal first concert experience for little ones.

What to Expect

Live appearances by JJ and friends from CoComelon

Guest performance by Blippi

Interactive singing and dancing

Colourful stage production and toddler-friendly sound levels

A safe, exciting environment for families with young kids

Event Details at a Glance

Dates: 27 and 28 September 2025

Venue: Sands Theatre, Marina Bay Sands

Showtimes: 11:00 AM, 2:30 PM, and 6:30 PM

Duration: 75 minutes (no intermission)

Age Group: Recommended for ages 2 to 6

Tickets: $78 to $138 (early bird discount from 8–11 May 2025)

Don’t Miss Out

CoComelon: Sing-A-Long LIVE! promises to be one of the biggest family events in Singapore this year. Whether you’re a fan of JJ’s cheerful tunes or Blippi’s educational fun, this show is a guaranteed crowd-pleaser.

Make this a school holiday your child will remember—book your tickets early and get ready to sing, dance, and laugh together.

item.content:encoded:
Gardens by the Bay has transformed into a tropical playground this June school holidays with the return of its annual Children’s Festival, running from 24 May to 15 June 2025 at Supertree Grove.

This year, the festival features Disney’s beloved duo, Lilo & Stitch, bringing the spirit of ‘ohana’—family, love, and belonging—to life through immersive play zones and interactive installations.

Slide into Adventure with The Great ‘Ohana Wave

The festival’s star attraction is The Great ‘Ohana Wave—a nearly 7-metre-tall, 28-metre-long slide that wraps around one of the iconic Supertrees. Designed for children aged 6 to 12, this thrilling ride offers young adventurers the chance to “surf” their way down in a safe and exhilarating experience.

Explore Four Stitch-Inspired Play Zones

Families can look forward to four themed activity stations:

Forest of Belonging: An inflatable playscape where kids can discover the meaning of ‘ohana’ through Stitch’s journey of belonging and adventure.

Space Adventure: A space-themed mission where children can race swing cars to power up light beams and complete their mission.

Stitch’s Mischief Makers: A creative zone where children can nurture creativity and sensory awareness through tactile play with kinetic sand.

Evening Magic with Garden Rhapsody

As the sun sets, visitors can enjoy a special edition of the nightly free Garden Rhapsody light and sound show titled The Way to ‘Ohana. The Supertrees come alive with lights synchronised to music inspired by Disney’s Lilo & Stitch, playing at 7:45 PM and 8:45 PM daily during the festival.

Event Details

Dates: 24 May – 15 June 2025

Time: 10:00 AM – 7:00 PM daily (Lilo & Stitch-themed installations close at 7:00 PM; queues close at 6:30 PM)

Location: Supertree Grove, Gardens by the Bay

Admission: Free (charges apply to selected activities)

For more information, visit the official event page.

Don’t miss this opportunity to create unforgettable memories with your little ones in a world where adventure meets the magic of Disney.

item.title: Saffron Milk During Pregnancy: Benefits, Safety, and Best Practices
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Joyce Almario
item.description: Discover if saffron milk is safe during pregnancy. Learn about its health benefits, recommended intake, potential risks, and preparation tips for expecting mothers.
item.content:encoded:
Every culture has its time-honored remedies for nurturing a healthy pregnancy, and few are as celebrated or as aromatic as saffron milk. While modern medicine plays a crucial role in prenatal care, ancient remedies still hold value for many expecting mothers. Among them, saffron milk, a golden-hued, aromatic drink steeped in tradition.

But how safe is it during pregnancy? Can a few strands of this luxurious spice truly benefit you and your baby?

This article blends time-honored wisdom with scientific research to uncover the truth about saffron milk during pregnancy.

 

What Is Saffron Milk?

Saffron milk, often called kesar doodh, is a warm beverage made by infusing milk with a few strands of saffron. It may include other ingredients like cardamom, almonds, or turmeric, depending on cultural or personal preferences. Saffron, derived from the Crocus sativus flower, is the world’s most expensive spice by weight, prized for its distinctive aroma, vibrant color, and therapeutic properties.

Traditionally used in Ayurvedic medicine, saffron milk is believed to boost immunity, improve complexion, and uplift mood. But during pregnancy, its benefits and risks warrant closer examination.

Is Saffron Milk Safe During Pregnancy?

Saffron Milk During Pregnancy: Benefits, Safety, and Best Practices

Yes, saffron milk can be safe during pregnancy when consumed in moderation. The key is dosage. While saffron offers several potential health benefits, excessive intake may lead to uterine contractions, especially in the first trimester.

Most healthcare professionals and nutritionists recommend limiting saffron consumption to 2 to 3 strands per day steeped in milk, particularly after the first trimester. The spice is potent, and more is not always better.

As always, it’s essential to consult your OB-GYN before adding any herbal or traditional remedies to your prenatal routine, especially if you have underlying health conditions.

Nutritional Benefits of Saffron Milk Rich in Antioxidants

Saffron contains powerful antioxidants like crocin, safranal, and kaempferol. These compounds help neutralize free radicals in the body, which can reduce inflammation and boost overall immunity.

Promotes Healthy Digestion

Digestive discomfort, including bloating and constipation, is common during pregnancy. Saffron has carminative properties that may soothe the digestive tract and improve metabolism when consumed in small quantities.

Supports Emotional Well-being and Reduces Stress

Hormonal fluctuations during pregnancy can affect mood. Saffron is known for its mild antidepressant effects and can help improve mood and reduce symptoms of anxiety and stress.

Clinical studies suggest saffron supplementation may even help with mild to moderate depression.

May Help with Blood Pressure Regulation

Some studies suggest saffron may support cardiovascular health by helping to regulate blood pressure and improve circulation. This is particularly helpful during pregnancy when blood volume increases and maintaining healthy blood pressure becomes crucial.

Cultural Beliefs Around Saffron in Pregnancy

In many Indian, Persian, and Middle Eastern cultures, saffron milk is traditionally believed to promote a fair complexion in babies, a belief not supported by science. However, its use in pregnancy is culturally linked to enhancing vitality, calming the mind, and nurturing the mother.

While these beliefs persist, modern healthcare professionals emphasize its nutritional rather than cosmetic value.

Potential Risks of Saffron Milk During Pregnancy Overconsumption and Uterine Contractions

Saffron in high doses (more than 5 grams) is considered unsafe and may stimulate uterine contractions, potentially leading to preterm labor or miscarriage. Always stick to small quantities, just 2 to 3 strands per serving.

Allergic Reactions

Though rare, saffron can trigger allergic reactions in some individuals, including dry mouth, dizziness, or nausea. Discontinue use and consult your doctor if any symptoms appear.

Impact on Blood Pressure for Sensitive Individuals

While saffron can help stabilize blood pressure, in some cases, it may cause slight drops. If you are prone to low blood pressure, discuss this with your healthcare provider before use.

Best Time to Drink Saffron Milk During Pregnancy

Saffron Milk During Pregnancy: Benefits, Safety, and Best Practices

Evening is often ideal, as saffron’s calming properties may help with better sleep. It can be introduced safely during the second trimester and continued in moderation through the third.

FAQs 1. Can saffron milk help with pregnancy mood swings?

Yes, saffron has natural mood-lifting properties and may help reduce anxiety and emotional stress during pregnancy.

2. Is it safe to drink saffron milk daily during pregnancy?

Yes, but only in small amounts—2–3 strands of saffron per day is the safe recommended limit.

3. When should I start drinking saffron milk while pregnant?

It’s best to start in the second trimester after consulting with your OB-GYN.

4. Does saffron milk affect baby’s complexion?

No, there is no scientific evidence that saffron influences skin color. Its benefits are nutritional and emotional.

5. How many saffron strands are safe to use during pregnancy?

Stick to 2–3 strands per day steeped in milk. Avoid excess to prevent adverse effects.

A Golden Elixir in Moderation

Saffron milk during pregnancy can be a warm, soothing, and nutritious addition to your diet provided it’s consumed responsibly. Rich in antioxidants, known for calming the nerves, and steeped in tradition, this luxurious spice offers more than just flavor.

Keep the dosage low, choose high-quality saffron, and always seek medical advice if unsure. As with many things in pregnancy, balance is everything.

Stick to 2–3 strands per day steeped in milk. Avoid excess to prevent adverse effects.

Saffron milk during pregnancy can be a warm, soothing, and nutritious addition to your diet provided it’s consumed responsibly. Rich in antioxidants, known for calming the nerves, and steeped in tradition, this luxurious spice offers more than just flavor.
Keep the dosage low, choose high-quality saffron, and always seek medical advice if unsure. As with many things in pregnancy, balance is everything.

item.content:encoded:
When you’re expecting, every bite and sip you take matters. From morning sickness to late-night cravings, pregnancy comes with its own set of nutritional puzzles. Among the growing range of plant-based alternatives, oat milk has quickly risen as a favorite. But is oat milk good for pregnancy?

If you’re curious about whether this creamy, dairy-free drink belongs in your prenatal diet, you’re not alone. Let’s explore how oat milk stacks up nutritionally, what benefits it offers for mom and baby, and what experts have to say.

 

Nutritional Benefits of Oat Milk During Pregnancy

Is Oat Milk Good for Pregnancy? Nutritional Benefits & Expert Advice

Oat milk brings a lot to the table especially for moms-to-be looking for a gentle, lactose-free milk option.

1. High in Fiber for Digestive Support

Pregnancy often slows digestion, leading to bloating and constipation. Oat milk, rich in soluble fiber like beta-glucan, promotes regular bowel movements and a healthy gut.

2. Fortified with Essential Nutrients

Most commercial oat milk brands are fortified with:

Calcium and Vitamin D: For fetal bone development

Vitamin B12: Supports neurological health

Folic Acid: Reduces risk of neural tube defects

3. Heart-Healthy and Low in Saturated Fat

Oat milk contains heart-supporting compounds like beta-glucans and is naturally low in saturated fats and cholesterol, making it a heart-smart choice during pregnancy.

4. Gentle on the Stomach and Allergen-Friendly

Oat milk is lactose-free, making it suitable for women with dairy intolerance. It’s also a safe option for those with soy or nut allergies, provided it’s certified gluten-free if needed.

Potential Drawbacks and Considerations

Despite its many benefits, oat milk isn’t perfect.

1. Lower in Protein

Compared to dairy or soy milk, oat milk has less protein. Ensure you’re supplementing with other protein-rich foods like legumes, eggs, or lean meats.

2. Watch for Added Sugars

Some flavored oat milks contain high levels of added sugar. Opt for unsweetened, fortified versions to keep your sugar intake in check.

3. Gluten Cross-Contamination

Though oats are naturally gluten-free, contamination can occur. If you’re gluten-sensitive, make sure to choose certified gluten-free oat milk.

Expert Recommendations

Is Oat Milk Good for Pregnancy? Nutritional Benefits & Expert Advice

Registered dietitians and obstetricians generally agree that oat milk is safe and beneficial during pregnancy when consumed in moderation. One to two servings per day can comfortably fit into a well-rounded prenatal diet, especially when using fortified brands.

FAQs 1. Can I drink oat milk every day while pregnant?

Yes, up to 1–2 servings daily of fortified, unsweetened oat milk is generally considered safe and beneficial.

2. Is oat milk safe in the first trimester?

Yes, its gentle nature and folic acid content support early fetal development and digestion.

3. Does oat milk have enough calcium for pregnancy?

Fortified oat milk typically contains similar calcium levels to cow’s milk. Always check the label.

4. Is oat milk good for gestational diabetes?

Unsweetened oat milk may be suitable due to its fiber content, but always consult your doctor.

5. Can oat milk cause bloating during pregnancy?

It’s generally easy to digest, but those sensitive to fiber or gluten should choose carefully.

A Comforting Choice With Nutritional Merit

So, is oat milk good for pregnancy? 100% YES, when chosen wisely. Its fiber content, fortification with essential nutrients, and smooth, comforting texture make it a wonderful addition to many prenatal diets. Just be mindful of added sugars and pair it with protein-rich foods to round out your nutrition.

As always, consult your healthcare provider to tailor your choices to your unique needs. With a little care, oat milk can be more than just a dairy alternative. It can be a nourishing companion on your journey to motherhood.

item.title: Is Soy Milk Good for Pregnancy? Benefits, Safety & Expert Advice
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Joyce Almario
item.description: Discover if soy milk is safe and beneficial during pregnancy. Learn about its nutrients, potential risks, and expert tips for expecting mothers.
item.content:encoded:
Pregnancy is a time of profound transformation, not only for your body but also for your lifestyle and dietary habits. With countless food and drink options vying for your attention, it’s natural to wonder: Is soy milk good for pregnancy?

As plant-based diets grow in popularity, many expecting mothers are turning to alternatives like soy milk.

This article breaks down the nutritional benefits, potential concerns, and expert recommendations to help you make an informed, confident choice for both you and your baby.

 

Understanding Soy Milk: What Is It?

Soy milk is a plant-based beverage made from soaked, ground, and boiled soybeans. It is naturally lactose-free and often fortified with essential vitamins and minerals, making it a popular dairy substitute. For pregnant women, its high protein content and rich nutrient profile can offer considerable benefits.

Nutritional Benefits of Soy Milk During Pregnancy

Is Soy Milk Good for Pregnancy? Benefits, Safety & Expert Advice

High-Quality Plant-Based Protein

Protein is a building block of life, essential for fetal tissue development. Soy milk provides approximately 7 grams of protein per cup, which supports muscle growth, organ formation, and overall fetal health.

Rich in Essential Vitamins and Minerals

Calcium: Fortified soy milk can offer up to 300 mg of calcium per serving, crucial for developing strong bones and teeth in your baby.

Vitamin D: Supports calcium absorption and enhances immune function.

Folic Acid: Reduces the risk of neural tube defects during early pregnancy.

Vitamin B12: Vital for red blood cell production and neurological function.

Cholesterol-Free and Low in Saturated Fats

Heart health matters more than ever during pregnancy. Soy milk is naturally cholesterol-free and low in saturated fats, contributing to a healthier cardiovascular profile.

Common Concerns About Soy Milk in Pregnancy Isoflavones and Hormonal Effects

Soy contains isoflavones, plant compounds that mimic estrogen. Some worry these may affect hormonal balance during pregnancy. However, scientific evidence shows that moderate soy consumption does not pose a risk to maternal or fetal health.

Allergies and Sensitivities

Soy is one of the top eight allergens. If you have a soy allergy or experience symptoms like bloating or hives, it’s best to avoid soy milk and consult your healthcare provider for safe alternatives.

Choosing the Right Type of Soy Milk

Fortified: Look for products enriched with calcium, vitamin D, and B12.

Organic and Non-GMO: Reduces exposure to pesticides and genetically modified ingredients.

Unsweetened: Minimizes added sugar intake, helping control weight and blood sugar levels.

Expert Recommendations for Soy Milk Intake

Health professionals including the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) and dietitians suggest that up to 1–2 servings of soy milk per day is safe and nutritious during pregnancy. It should be consumed as part of a varied and balanced prenatal diet.

How to Incorporate Soy Milk Into Your Pregnancy Diet

Is Soy Milk Good for Pregnancy? Benefits, Safety & Expert Advice

Use in smoothies with leafy greens and fruits for a vitamin-packed drink.

Replace dairy milk in oatmeal or cereal.

Use in baking or cooking for creaminess without lactose.

When to Avoid Soy Milk During Pregnancy

Avoid soy milk if you have a diagnosed soy allergy or have been advised by your healthcare provider to limit phytoestrogen intake. Always choose reputable brands and check labels for added sugars and additives.

FAQs 1. Can I drink soy milk every day during pregnancy?

Yes, drinking 1–2 servings of soy milk daily is generally safe and beneficial for pregnant women, provided it’s part of a balanced diet.

2. Is soy milk safe during the first trimester?

Yes, soy milk is safe in the first trimester and can support early fetal development due to its folic acid and protein content.

3. What are the alternatives to soy milk during pregnancy?

Almond milk, oat milk, and fortified rice milk are great alternatives if you are allergic to soy or prefer a different taste.

4. Does soy milk increase estrogen levels in pregnancy?

Soy contains phytoestrogens, but studies show that moderate consumption does not significantly affect estrogen levels in pregnant women.

5. Can soy milk cause miscarriage?

There is no scientific evidence linking moderate soy milk consumption to miscarriage. Always consult with your doctor for peace of mind.

Sip Smart, Stay Strong

So, is soy milk good for pregnancy? Absolutely! When chosen wisely and consumed in moderation, it can be a valuable part of a nourishing prenatal diet. Packed with plant-based protein, essential nutrients, and free from lactose, soy milk serves as a supportive ally in your pregnancy journey.

Just remember to consult your healthcare provider for personalized advice and opt for fortified, organic, unsweetened versions whenever possible.

item.title: ‘She’s Not Less, Just Simply Wired Differently’—A Singapore Mum Gets Real About Autism Parenting
item.dc:creator: Miko Pagaduan
item.description: Community is out there. And your child — just like Amelie — is more than their diagnosis.
item.content:encoded:
You never forget the moment your world shifts. For Benita, 43, that moment came quietly but decisively — not with a dramatic announcement, but during what was supposed to be a routine check-up at KK Women’s and Children’s Hospital. Her daughter Amelie, then just shy of three years old, had been admitted for a febrile seizure.

But something else caught the doctor’s attention.

When asked for her name, Amelie didn’t respond. She wasn’t engaging the way most children her age typically would.

That small interaction sparked a journey that would forever change how Benita saw her daughter — and herself. After a referral to a Developmental and Behavioural Paediatrician, the confirmation came.

Amelie was on the autism spectrum.

As a parent, you might find yourself grappling with the same storm of emotions. Denial. Guilt. Sleepless nights filled with questions. Benita did.

“I spent nights crying, questioning what had gone wrong — from my pregnancy to my parenting,” she recalls. “The diagnosis hit hard. There was guilt, fear, and deep uncertainty.”

 

Living With Autism is Not Less — Just Different

It’s okay to grieve the expectations you had. It’s okay to feel lost at first. But Benita wants you to know that a diagnosis of autism isn’t a life sentence. It’s a different roadmap. And it can be a gift. For her, receiving Amelie’s diagnosis brought not despair, but clarity.

“It gave me permission to understand and accept her for who she truly is, rather than trying to fit her into neurotypical milestones,” she shares.

That acceptance shifted everything. She stopped trying to correct behaviours like stimming or delayed responses. She began to build a parenting style that was structured yet loving, one that gave Amelie the predictability and clarity she needed to thrive.

As a parent, you might feel like you’re drowning in unknowns. But as Benita’s story shows, the journey through autism can become one of empowerment, understanding, and even joy.

“It took time to accept that Amelie was not “less,” but simply wired differently. “

 

When Support Systems Fall Short

In Singapore, early intervention services do exist — but they’re often hard to access. After Amelie’s diagnosis, Benita was advised to enrol her in government-provided therapy. What she quickly discovered was how limited those sessions were.

“Sometimes it was only once a quarter. It wasn’t enough,” she says. “We needed something more intensive.”

So she did what many parents in her position do: she became a researcher, advocate, and warrior — all in one. Books, podcasts, online searches — she left no stone unturned.

That’s how she found Bridging the Gap (BtG) in 2022. The multidisciplinary, integrated approach they offered was a breath of fresh air. For families looking for more than a piecemeal solution, BtG became a lifeline.

Source: BtG

 

The Cost of Care

If you’re raising a child with autism, you know the financial strain is real. Therapy, assessments, specialist consultations — they all add up. For Benita’s family of six, surviving on one income, it wasn’t easy.

“Budgeting for Amelie’s therapy was tough,” she says. But there was more than just the financial cost. There was the emotional one, too.

“I had to educate myself from scratch on what autism really meant,” she shares. “There’s no manual. You’re constantly learning, adapting, and sometimes, failing.”

But she kept going — driven by love, by hope, and by the strength of her support system.

Her husband, she says, has been her greatest pillar. Together, they’ve learned to lean on each other. And with BtG offering consistent, evidence-based care, they began to feel less alone.

 

Small Wins, Big Milestones

Since starting at BtG, Amelie’s progress has been profound. She’s more focused, communicates more clearly, and is learning to navigate the world with increasing independence.

“She can now balance on one foot, write with proper grip, and even wait safely to cross the road,” Benita shares proudly.

These may seem like small milestones to others — but to a parent of a child with autism, they are everything. They are hard-won, deeply cherished, and proof that early, holistic intervention makes a difference.

 

Autism and the Long Road to Emotional Endurance

As the years have passed, Benita has grown into her role as a caregiver with wisdom, patience, and emotional resilience. But the toll is real.

“It’s been a journey of joy, worry, exhaustion, and growth,” she admits.

If you’re in the thick of it right now, know this: you’re not weak for feeling tired. You’re not failing for needing help. And you deserve a support system that holds you up when you can’t do it alone. For Benita, that includes her husband, her community, and centres like BtG that walk this road with families every step of the way.

 

True Inclusion Starts With Us

Autism is not just a condition to be managed — it’s a way of seeing the world. And that world, Benita argues, needs to do better.

“True inclusion means recognising that every child — regardless of ability — deserves to be seen, supported, and accepted,” she says.

Buzzwords won’t change hearts. Actions will. Inclusion means training educators, redesigning public spaces, and most importantly, teaching our own children that different is not deficient.

If Amelie is to thrive in Singapore, we all need to make space for her — and others like her — to belong.

 

This Autistic Pride Day, Let’s Walk With Families Like Benita’s

Source: Adobe Stock

As Autistic Pride Day approaches on June 18, take a moment to reflect not just on the triumphs of the Autistic community, but also on the journey families like Benita’s have walked.

Autism isn’t something to fear — it’s something to understand.

If you’re a parent navigating this journey, know that you are not alone. Support is out there. Community is out there. And your child — just like Amelie — is more than their diagnosis. They are capable of growing, thriving, and teaching you a whole new way of seeing the world.

Take a breath. Ask for help. Tell your story. And most importantly — keep going.

Need support? Reach out to ECDA-recognised centres like Bridging the Gap. Because your journey matters — and you don’t have to walk it alone.

So she did what many parents in her position do: she became a researcher, advocate, and warrior — all in one. Books, podcasts, online searches — she left no stone unturned.
That’s how she found Bridging the Gap (BtG) in 2022. The multidisciplinary, integrated approach they offered was a breath of fresh air. For families looking for more than a piecemeal solution, BtG became a lifeline.

But she kept going — driven by love, by hope, and by the strength of her support system.

These may seem like small milestones to others — but to a parent of a child with autism, they are everything. They are hard-won, deeply cherished, and proof that early, holistic intervention makes a difference.
 
Autism and the Long Road to Emotional Endurance
As the years have passed, Benita has grown into her role as a caregiver with wisdom, patience, and emotional resilience. But the toll is real.

“It’s been a journey of joy, worry, exhaustion, and growth,” she admits.

If you're in the thick of it right now, know this: you’re not weak for feeling tired. You’re not failing for needing help. True Inclusion Starts With Us
Autism is not just a condition to be managed — it’s a way of seeing the world. And that world, Benita argues, needs to do better.

Buzzwords won’t change hearts. Actions will. Inclusion means training educators, redesigning public spaces, and most importantly, teaching our own children that different is not deficient.
If Amelie is to thrive in Singapore, we all need to make space for her — and others like her — to belong.

As Autistic Pride Day approaches on June 18, take a moment to reflect not just on the triumphs of the Autistic community, but also on the journey families like Benita’s have walked.
Autism isn’t something to fear — it’s something to understand.
If you’re a parent navigating this journey, know that you are not alone. Support is out there. Community is out there. And your child — just like Amelie — is more than their diagnosis. They are capable of growing, thriving, and teaching you a whole new way of seeing the world.
Take a breath. Ask for help. Tell your story. And most importantly — keep going.
Need support? Reach out to ECDA-recognised centres like Bridging the Gap. Because your journey matters — and you don’t have to walk it alone.
